results.title: The Grapevine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Office Supervisor’s Problems”.
Two girls discuss of rumour that they have heard that their company is merging with another company which would mean moving to another city. On another occasion new office equipment is obtained and the rumour is spread that girls are being replaced by machines. The office manager when confronted with the stories says there is no truth in them. He has not been generous in answering questions and they were nervous about going to him. The question for discuss is how rumour can be prevented from being started.

results.title: The Grand
results.brief_description: Describes the work done by people of various backgrounds for conservation on the Grand River Watershed in Ontario, Canada. Also gives the background to the work and explains various methods of conservation used in the watershed area.

results.title: The Golden West USA
results.brief_description: A tour of the western states of America, taking in San Francisco, Virginia City, left to die after the gold rushes, Salt Lake City, home of the Mormons, the surrounding “dinosaur country”, the splendour of a Grand Canyon sunset, the vast deserts of New Mexico, exciting Los Angeles with its Disneyland and Hollywood studios, and finally a trip up the majestic Pacific coast.

results.title: The Golden age of the automobile
results.creator_credit: Helen Jean Secondari and John H. Secondari
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the automobile from its early years as a plaything of the rich, through Henry Ford’s development of the Model T for the average worker, to the present day when its proliferation has altered the face of the western world. Suitable for upper primary and secondary level.

results.title: The Golden age of steam: locomotives
results.brief_description: Remember the days of the steam-train and the wonderful sound of the locomotive engine? Then this documentary will take you back in history, to the “golden age of steam”. Produced and filmed in Britain, and containing some rare archival footage, the program presents an historical look at the steam locomotive, including the replica (built in the 1970s) of George Stephenson’s “Rocket”. Also shows examples of such well-known company names as Fenchurch, Stowe, Wainwright and Pennine Ltd which are still running today. Photographed in some of Britain’s beautiful countryside, these locomotives are seen winding through small villages, climbing up steep grades and passing through busy stations. One of the best attributes of the documentary is that it contains minimal commentary allowing the viewer to experience the sound and atmosphere of a bygone era.

results.title: The Games: Olympic Variations
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Auder’s alternative vision of the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles is composed entirely of re-scanned and re-edited footage shot directly from a television set. The athletes’ exertions, fragmented and abstracted by Auder into an incessant flow of crotch shots and body parts, take on a highly sexual, often sadomasochistic edge. Auder exploits the subliminal, raising the violent and sexual subtext of TV sports coverage to the surface. His seamlessly re-edited images and discordant sound pull the viewer into an enigmatic narrative of physicality that is intensely subjective, almost obsessive, in its focus. The underlying principle behind appropriation and ‘scratch’ video of this kind is an inclination to subvert, artistically, the political ideology reflected in the industrial source of the material and TV entertainment (Bob Riley).

results.title: The Fur seal
results.brief_description: A complete photographic study of the fur seal in one of their main habitats - the Pribilof Islands in the Bering Sea. Investigates the fur seals’ evolution, adaptation to its environment and habits.

results.title: The Foundations of wealth. Part 1. How it all began
results.brief_description: Uses animation and docuemtary footage to establish the concept of living at subsistence level. Shows how vulnerable people are when they need to consume everything they produce in order to survive and points towards the concept of creating a surplus. Suitable for secondary school level.
